article:
'Dephosphorylation' is the essential process of removing phosphate groups from
an organic compound (as adenosine triphosphate (ATP)) by hydrolysis. Its
opposite is phosphorylation. It is found in muscle movement as well as many
other reactions within the body, as well as reactions in plants.

For example, ATP is hydrolysed to adenosine diphosphate (ADP) with the release
of energy, phosphate groups, and ADP in the active transport of sucrose
molecules into a phloem vessel in a plant.
